projects.name: Kristian Augusts gate 13 (KA13)

project_type.description: 1950s office building transformed to modern workplace with 80% material reuse

projects.circularity_qualification: Norway's first major building to achieve 80% material reuse by weight, sourcing materials from over 25 donor buildings across Oslo including structural concrete from Regjeringskvartalet.

circular_features.description: 21 hollow-core concrete slabs reused as floor dividers - Norway's first structural concrete reuse at scale
circular_features.processing: SINTEF tested slabs to establish certification pathways

citations.source: Anskaffelser.no - Ombruk hos Statsbygg og Entra
citations.quote: 168 tonn betong i form av store betongelementer (hulldekker) ble flyttet fra Regjeringskvartalet til Tullinløkka
Hulldekkeelementene ble skjært løs og heist ut fra R4 i november 2019

citations.source: Heidelberg Materials Prefab - Ombruk av hulldekker
citations.quote: 21 hulldekker fra Regjeringskvartalet installert i plan 5 til 8

circular_features.description: Windows from mistaken bulk order saved 90% production emissions

citations.quote: Vinduer fra feilbestilling i Kværnerbyen sparte 90% produksjonsutslipp

circular_features.description: Railings repurposed as atrium stairs
Stone from facade renovation transformed into terrace decking

cost_notes.cost_comparison: Reuse was neither simple nor cheap to implement - goal was to prove feasibility. Higher upfront costs but creating replicable procedures.

projects.notes: Norway's breakthrough reuse project. Produced 116-page experience report documenting challenges and solutions. QR codes throughout building for material traceability. FutureBuilt organized 4-5 workshops during 2018-2019 to develop quality control procedures. DOGA jury confirmed project is 'economically feasible, yes, even profitable.' Several material groups achieved >90% CO2 savings vs new.

narrative.driver: Entra wanted to demonstrate that material reuse could be economically viable at scale, transforming their 1950s office building into a showcase for circular construction. The project aimed to prove that ombruk could be systematic, not just symbolic.
narrative.lessons_learned: The 116-page experience report documents key findings: procurement must start early (12+ months), SINTEF testing established certification pathways for structural concrete, and QR codes enable material traceability. The project proved circular construction can be profitable.

build_nothing_new.notes: 1960s structure fully preserved, transformed function, +40 year lifespan

build_for_longterm.notes: Documented material sources for future reference

build_efficiently.notes: Standard office efficiency

build_with_right_materials.notes: 168t concrete, glass, steel, stone from 25+ donor buildings

cbc_assessment.notes: SINTEF-verified structural concrete reuse. DOGA Hedersmerke 2021.

has: Material types: concrete, glass, steel, stone
Technical reports: KA13 Erfaringsrapport Ombruk (, Insenti - Erfaringsrapport fra
Donor sources: Tøyenbadet swimming pool, Regjeringskvartalet R4 building, Skøyen facade renovation
data_completeness.upgrade_path: To reach Grade A: Document cost savings from reuse; Obtain klimagassregnskap/LCA report

projects.name: Skur 38

project_type.description: 1915 warehouse transformed to Oslo Havn headquarters preserving Norway's first reinforced concrete building

projects.circularity_qualification: Rehabilitation of one of Norway's first reinforced concrete buildings from 1915 into modern headquarters, preserving entire concrete structure and achieving BREEAM-NOR Excellent.

circular_features.description: Entire 1915 reinforced concrete warehouse structure preserved - one of Norway's first reinforced concrete buildings
Original ship deck flooring repurposed as wall cladding

citations.quote: 171 tonn CO2-ekvivalenter redusert gjennom gjenbruk av byggematerialer
Spileveggen i kantina satt sammen av mahogny treverk fra den gamle fjerdeetasjen

circular_features.description: Fire doors renovated and reused; old railings cleaned and extended
Futurecem concrete with 35%+ clinker replaced by calcined clay and limestone meal - Norwegian first at large scale
Isokalk facade system - mineral-based mortar with aerogel spheres for thin insulation on heritage building

narrative.driver: Oslo Havn needed a new headquarters and chose to rehabilitate their historic 1915 warehouse rather than demolish. The project aimed to demonstrate that heritage preservation and modern environmental standards (BREEAM Excellent) could coexist, while reducing climate emissions through material reuse.
narrative.lessons_learned: The collaborative contract (samspillsentreprise) with multiple workshops was crucial for handling such an innovative project. Good risk assessment and continuous team development with clear roles helped resolve problems along the way. Using Loopfront database to map reusable materials from both Skur 38 and other projects enabled creative solutions. Some salvaged components couldn't be used as planned, while others found new applications through creative thinking.

projects.notes: Possibly first building from 1915 to achieve BREEAM-NOR Excellent. Heritage-protected yellow-listed warehouse. Samspillsentreprise (collaboration contract) enabled adaptive problem-solving. 160 workplaces. Materials stored in Kongshavn rock hall during assessment. Project duration June 2021 - October 2022.

build_efficiently.notes: Multi-use building: o, f, f, i, c, e

cbc_assessment.notes: Heritage transformation of 1915 building - 171t CO2 saved

has: Material types: concrete, fixtures, insulation, timber
Donor sources: Original building, Original 1915 structure
data_completeness.upgrade_path: To reach Grade B: Obtain klimagassregnskap/LCA report; Document cost savings from reuse

projects.name: Eikeli videregående skole

project_type.description: New school building using 650m² CE-certified reclaimed Danish brick

projects.circularity_qualification: Norway's first large building with 650 m² of CE-certified reclaimed brick facade, proving scalability of certified reused materials.

circular_features.description: 650 m² CE-certified reclaimed brick facade - Norway's first large building with CE-certified reclaimed brick. Brick sourced from Danish demolition sites, supplied by Norwegian company HØINE AS.
circular_features.processing: Three test walls (1.5x1.5m each) verified mortar and shear strength before final selection

citations.source: Byggmesteren - Norges første skole i ombrukstegl
citations.quote: 650 kvm CE-merket ombrukstegl - Norges første større bygg
Dansk ombrukstegl levert til fasade på nytt tilbygg
Spart 106 tonn avfall og 26,5 tonn CO2

circular_features.description: Old gym converted into cafeteria and group rooms

cost_notes.cost_comparison: Reused brick is now competitive with new quality brick - "ikke lenger dyrere enn ny kvalitetstegl"
cost_notes.labor_note: More labor-intensive, thus more expensive work, but savings on material cost balance out
cost_notes.environmental_savings: 106 tonnes waste avoided, 26.5 tonnes CO2 saved (equiv. Oslo-Copenhagen 265 times)
cost_notes.key_insight: First large-scale CE-certified reused brick project in Norway

other_stakeholders.name: HØINE AS
other_stakeholders.contribution: CE-certified reclaimed brick from Danish demolition sites

sources.name: Byggmesteren - Norges første skole i ombrukstegl
Peab - Første store prosjekt med ombrukstegl

projects.notes: First fossil-free construction site for large building in Norway. Flow batteries for energy storage reduce lithium dependency. Proved CE-certified reclaimed brick viable at scale. Reuse saves 100x more emissions than producing new brick.

narrative.driver: Viken fylkeskommune aimed to prove CE-certified reclaimed brick is viable at scale in Norway. Project demonstrates that 100x emission reduction is achievable vs new brick production.
narrative.lessons_learned: Three test walls (1.5m x 1.5m each) verified mortar and shear strength before full installation. HØINE AS proved Norwegian supply chain for Danish reclaimed brick. Process is now replicable for other projects.

build_efficiently.notes: Standard school efficiency

build_with_right_materials.notes: 650m² CE-certified reclaimed Danish brick via HØINE AS

cbc_assessment.notes: First Norwegian project with CE-certified reclaimed brick at scale

projects.name: Nedre Sem låve

project_type.description: 1887 stone barn transformed to public meeting house

projects.size_notes: Including 275 m² technical loft under roof
projects.circularity_qualification: Norway's first EU Circular Cities and Regions Initiative pilot achieving 50% circularity through meticulous stone-by-stone and brick-by-brick dismantling of 1887 barn.

circular_features.description: Natural stone foundation dismantled stone-by-stone, cleaned, sorted, rebuilt as lower facade

citations.quote: 1887 steinfjøs transformert til forsamlingshus
50% sirkulære materialer - stein, tegl, treverk

circular_features.description: Red brick from cow barn dismantled brick-by-brick, reused in sections with characteristic arched windows
Red barn panel cladding sorted, planed, reinforced, remounted with original bead profiles
Structural timber donated to TradLab TRE - documented material flow between FutureBuilt projects
Extreme low-carbon concrete with 100% recycled crushed concrete aggregate
Custom EPS insulation from 100% recycled fish boxes (developed by Bewi specifically for this project)
Reclaimed radiators instead of plastic floor heating cables

cost_notes.key_insight: 50% circularity achieved - first circular building project for Asker kommune

programs.name: EU Circular Cities and Regions Initiative (CCRI)

other_stakeholders.name: Bewi
other_stakeholders.contribution: Custom EPS from recycled fish boxes

projects.notes: Houses carpentry workshop, commercial kitchen, farm shop, 6 care apartments. 41 total users (10 staff, 10 residents, 21 work center participants). Original 1876/1887 barn carefully dismantled winter 2022-2023 with every material catalogued. FutureBuilt pilot for plastic-free building criteria. Opened June 2024. Documented as cost-neutral with traditional construction approach (150 MNOK). Timber cladding sent to Stiltre at Kongsberg for planing. Goal: 100% reused materials in outdoor areas. Pergola built from old barn's bearing line.

narrative.driver: Asker kommune wanted to demonstrate traditional building preservation can meet modern sustainability standards. As Norway's first EU CCRI pilot, the project documents inter-project material flows (timber to TradLab TRE).
narrative.lessons_learned: Stone-by-stone and brick-by-brick dismantling preserves material value. Bewi fish box EPS proves waste-stream upcycling is viable. Project achieved cost neutrality with traditional approach - circular is not more expensive.

build_nothing_new.notes: 1887 stone barn walls preserved, new function as meeting house

build_for_longterm.notes: Materials documented, some donated to TradLab TRE

build_efficiently.notes: Adaptive reuse of existing footprint

build_with_right_materials.notes: 50% circular materials - stone, brick, timber. Fish-box EPS insulation.

cbc_assessment.notes: Exemplary rural heritage transformation. Stiltre timber processing.

has: Material types: brick, concrete, fixtures, insulation, stone, timber
Donor sources: 1887 barn on site, 1890 barn (unsuitable for bearing loads), Fish box waste stream
data_completeness.upgrade_path: To reach Grade B: Obtain klimagassregnskap/LCA report; Document cost savings from reuse

projects.name: Løren aktivitetspark og flerbrukshall

project_type.description: New sports facility with world-first ship steel structure reuse

projects.circularity_qualification: World's first building with load-bearing steel structure from decommissioned ship (Curlew FPSO), plus concrete facade elements from demolished school.

circular_features.description: World's first ship-to-shore structural reuse: load-bearing steel from decommissioned Curlew FPSO vessel for pergola roof structure
circular_features.processing: AF Offshore Decom cut steel plates from hull, cleaned, fabricated into structural beams. Nordic Circles developed dismantling methodology.

citations.quote: Verdens første byggeprosjekt med oppsirkulert skipsstål som bærende konstruksjon

citations.source: KlimaOslo - Stål fra skip i nytt bygg
citations.quote: 90% klimagassbesparelse sammenlignet med nytt stål
Curlew FPSO opererte i Nordsjøen i 20 år før pensjonering
97% lavere klimafotavtrykk enn vanlig stål

circular_features.description: Concrete facade elements from demolished school stored at central reuse warehouse
circular_features.processing: Stored at Oslo kommune central reuse warehouse near Løren, validated by Resirqel

cost_notes.ship_steel_savings: 97% lower climate footprint than conventional steel, ~90% CO2 savings
cost_notes.key_insight: World first: upcycled ship steel in load-bearing construction

construction_site.note: 100% fossil-free from Jan 2025, large proportion emission-free from May 2023

sources.name: Statsbygg - Stål fra skip blir grønne bærebjelker
Stålbygg - Ombruk av skip og offshore konstruksjoner

projects.notes: 2,500 m² multi-purpose hall + 6,000 m² outdoor activity park. Global first: ship steel structural reuse. Hall partially below grade with activities on roof. Focus on physical activity for girls and youth with disabilities. Features volleyball, badminton, basketball, dance studios, strength training, equipment lending.

narrative.driver: Oslo kommune wanted to pioneer ship-to-building steel reuse, creating a globally unique methodology for offshore decommissioning material in construction. Demonstrates circular economy bridge between maritime and building sectors.
narrative.lessons_learned: AF Offshore Decom methodology proved ship steel can meet structural requirements. Systematic warehouse validation (413 concrete elements from Stig school) shows municipal material banking is viable.

build_for_longterm.notes: Ship steel structure documented for future disassembly

build_efficiently.notes: Multi-use sports facility, efficient material use

build_with_right_materials.notes: World-first ship steel reuse for building structure

cbc_assessment.notes: Pioneering methodology for ship steel certification (Nordic Circles/DNV)

has: Project name: Løren aktivitetspark og flerbrukshall
CO2 baseline: Ship steel vs new production

projects.name: Treklang / Oksenøya Senter

project_type.description: New timber school designed for disassembly

projects.circularity_qualification: Comprehensive Design for Disassembly at massive scale (37,000 m²), with demountable steel and concrete connections, 55% recycled steel, enabling future material recovery.

circular_features.description: 3 hollow-core concrete slabs reused from Regjeringskvartalet (government quarter demolition)
Demountable steel and concrete connections throughout bearing system - elements can be disconnected and relocated
55% recycled construction steel in bearing system
Low-carbon hollow-core decks (lavkarbon hulldekker) and CEM III B concrete throughout
circular_features.specifications: CEM III B sement, lavkarbon klasse A

circular_features.description: Prefabricated massive timber elements for nursing home and kindergarten, enabling future reconfiguration
Solar panels producing 111,000 kWh/year, seawater heat pumps for local district heating/cooling

sources.name: Klimagassrapport Oksenøya skole (Asplan Viak/OneClickLCA)
sources.notes: Detailed GHG calculations per NS 3720, includes breakdown by materials, energy, transport

projects.notes: Integrated three functions: 12,950 m² school (BRA) + 14,000 m² nursing home + 8,000 m² kindergarten = 32,000 m² total complex. Name 'Treklang' means 'three-chord' - inspired by timber facades on all three buildings. 51.9% total GHG reduction vs reference. 3 hollow-core slabs reused from Regjeringskvartalet. Solar panels produce 111,000 kWh/year. Seawater heat pumps for local district heating/cooling. Future-focused approach: today's reversible construction becomes tomorrow's donor building inventory.

narrative.driver: Bærum kommune wanted to demonstrate that large-scale timber construction with high environmental ambitions is achievable for public buildings. The project combines kindergarten, school and sports facilities in one integrated complex.
narrative.lessons_learned: Design for disassembly requires early planning and coordination between all parties. Material choices must account for future flexibility.
challenges: Coordinating multiple functions in single building

build_efficiently.notes: Co-located school, kindergarten, sports hall

cbc_assessment.notes: Oksenøya Senter: 28-34% CO2 reduction, massivtre, Passivhus, BREEAM Excellent

data_completeness.upgrade_path: To reach Grade B: Obtain klimagassregnskap/LCA report; Document material origin/donor buildings

projects.name: Ruseløkka skole

project_type.description: New school with reclaimed materials from predecessor

projects.circularity_qualification: Pilot project to systematize material reuse in Oslo's school program, backed by Oslo City Council political mandate, establishing testing and documentation protocols.

circular_features.description: 4,500 bricks from demolished school reused for interior non-load-bearing walls (facade brick failed compressive strength testing)

citations.quote: 4500 resirkulerbare murstein, trebjelker og granittblokker sikret fra gammel skole
Granitt fra gammel trapp og grunnmur gjenbrukt i uteområdet

circular_features.description: Granite from internal stairs and foundation reused in outdoor areas and as base/plinth
Play equipment dismounted and remounted at other Oslo schools (including Sørkedalen skole)
Fire alarm components reused in replacement building
28 old doors sold via Finn.no before demolition - extending life through consumer resale
Lavkarbon Ekstrem concrete (CEM III/b) with 60% CO2 reduction vs standard concrete

citations.quote: Lavkarbon Ekstrem lavkarbonbetong, med klassifisering CEM III/b

circular_features.description: Facade-integrated and rooftop solar panels producing 80,000 kWh/year
New brick walls with lime mortar for future reuse (not cement mortar)

citations.quote: Veggene med brukt murstein ble murt med kalkmørtel - ikke sementmørtel for at mursteinen skal kunne gjenbrukes i neste byggeprosjekt

sources.name: Klimagassregnskap As-built (Asplan Viak)
sources.notes: 33-page as-built climate gas report documenting 61% total GHG reduction

projects.notes: Queen Sonja inaugurated. Capacity: 690 students + 74 staff (9,822 m² BRA). 61% GHG reduction documented in as-built klimagassregnskap. Passivhus standard. Fossil-free construction site. 700 m² solar panels producing 80,000 kWh/year. Rooftop terrace with greenhouse. Testing revealed facade brick lacked compressive strength for load-bearing - important lesson for future projects.

narrative.driver: Oslo kommune aimed to build a climate-neutral school while preserving local heritage. The old school materials - 4,500 bricks, timber beams, and granite blocks - were carefully salvaged for reuse.
narrative.lessons_learned: Heritage materials require careful documentation and testing. Dynamic glass reduces energy consumption significantly.
challenges: Preserving historic elements while meeting modern standards

build_for_longterm.notes: Lime mortar for future brick reuse, flexible school design

build_efficiently.notes: 61% total GHG reduction (34% materials, 74% energy)

build_with_right_materials.notes: 4,500 reused bricks, Lavkarbon Ekstrem concrete, 80,000 kWh/year solar

cbc_assessment.notes: Strong documentation with as-built klimagassregnskap. Exemplary new build with 61% CO2 reduction and design for future material recovery.

has: Material types: brick, concrete, fixtures, solar, stone
data_completeness.upgrade_path: Flagship documentation level achieved. Maintain with updates as project progresses.

projects.name: TradLab TRE

project_type.description: Demonstration workshop with materials from Nedre Sem

projects.circularity_qualification: Demonstrates inter-project material transfer (timber from Nedre Sem barn) and validates traditional Norwegian construction techniques as inherently circular.

circular_features.description: Timber beams from 1890 barn used as bearing structure and floor joists between floors
circular_features.processing: Documented inter-project transfer between two FutureBuilt projects

circular_features.description: Remaining Nedre Sem timber used as 'kubb' (wooden blocks) in walls - traditional technique combining timber blocks with clay insulation
Heavy binding framework with standardized 6-inch timber, minimal nails, designed for future disassembly and reuse after centuries
Additional timber from Nordmarka forest via pluckhogst (selective logging), transported by horse and sled to minimize impact

metrics.inter_project_transfer: First documented material flow between two FutureBuilt projects

scope_notes.notes: Museum pavilion/workshop at Norsk Folkemuseum - demonstration project for traditional crafts, not a functional public building. Valuable for material flow documentation (timber from Nedre Sem).

projects.notes: Janus-faced design: modern facade toward Festplassen, traditional toward Østlandstunet. Ground floor carpenter workshops, second floor 'spikkotek' (children's carpentry library). Tests whether traditional techniques inherently embody circular principles. Embodies architect's philosophy of 'staying with the trouble'. Completed December 2024.

narrative.driver: Norsk Folkemuseum wanted to create a living demonstration of traditional craft techniques using reused materials, specifically the timber donated from Nedre Sem låve.
narrative.lessons_learned: Traditional techniques like "kubb" (wooden blocks in clay) can be applied with modern materials. Inter-project material flow creates valuable connections.
challenges: Adapting old timber to new construction

has: Donor sources: Nedre Sem låve (1890 barn), Nedre Sem låve, Nordmarka forest + Vikingtidsmuseet construction plot
data_completeness.upgrade_path: Priority improvements: Obtain klimagassregnskap/LCA report; Document reuse/circularity percentage

projects.name: Sirkulær Ressurssentral

project_type.description: Circular material bank and logistics hub

projects.client: Sirkulær Ressurssentral AS (100% owned by Foreningen Pådriv Oslo)
projects.circularity_qualification: One of Europe's largest reuse centers for building materials, solving the 'time mismatch' problem between demolition and construction schedules through logistics infrastructure.

circular_features.description: 4,500 m² indoor warehouse + 2,500 m² outdoor storage enabling material banking between projects
Main structure is tent donated from Statsbygg (Regjeringskvartalet construction)
Example flow: 413 concrete facade elements from Stig school → stored → validated by Resirqel → supplied to Løren project

scope_notes.notes: Material banking/distribution facility (4,500 m² tent from Regjeringskvartalet). Enables circular economy but is infrastructure, not a building with material circularity as end product.

projects.notes: Opened March 14, 2023. Non-profit (ideelt) structure emphasizes mission over profit. Solves chronic 'time mismatch' problem. National Knowledge Arena gathers 30+ industry actors for workshops on contracts, documentation, BREEAM, residential reuse.

narrative.driver: Oslo needed centralized infrastructure for material reuse at scale. The tent itself is reused from Regjeringskvartalet demolition - a fitting symbol.
narrative.lessons_learned: Material banking requires partnerships across the construction industry. Location in active development area (Hovinbyen) is key for material flow.

has: Client: Sirkulær Ressurssentral AS (100% owned by Foreningen Pådriv Oslo)
data_completeness.upgrade_path: To reach Grade B: Obtain klimagassregnskap/LCA report; Document cost savings from reuse

projects.name: Nøstebukten Brygge

project_type.description: New housing using 70% materials from donor building on same site

projects.circularity_qualification: 70% reuse target through systematic deconstruction of former TV2 headquarters, with 3D scanning mapping 1,200 m³ timber and 2,800 tonnes brick before demolition.

circular_features.description: 1,200 m³ timber mapped via 3D scanning before deconstruction; floor boards become exterior cladding painted in historic Bergen harbor colors

citations.quote: 1200 kubikk tre og 2800 tonn tegl identifisert via 3D-skanning
Gulvbord bearbeides til utvendig kledning - males i historiske farger

circular_features.description: 2,800 tonnes brick offered as upgrade options for interior apartment walls; also featured in entrances and rooftop terraces
Facade plates, sprinkler pipes, structural timber carefully demounted (nails removed individually)

breakdown.note: 1,200 m³ timber including floor boards and structural

narrative.driver: OBOS sought to demonstrate large-scale residential material circularity by transforming the former TV2 headquarters site rather than conventional demolition. The project aimed to prove that 70% material reuse is achievable in housing development while maintaining commercial viability.
narrative.lessons_learned: 3D scanning before deconstruction was crucial - it revealed 1,200 m³ timber and 2,800 tonnes brick that would otherwise have been waste. Strong local democracy through multiple stakeholder meetings with neighbors, city planners, and local associations was essential for community acceptance. The historic Bergen harbor aesthetic (colors, materials) became a design asset rather than constraint.

sources.name: EnergiAktuelt - 70% gjenbruk når TV2-hovedkvarter blir leiligheter

projects.notes: 96 apartments plus maritime kindergarten and common garden. Establishes Bergen's FutureBuilt program (launched 2023). Ship-to-shore concept: donor and recipient are same site. District-scale circularity: materials serve both on-site and nearby projects. Residents can 'literally live within materials from site's history'. Featured in NTNU doctoral research on circular economy barriers.

build_efficiently.notes: Multi-use building: h, o, u, s, i, n, g

cbc_assessment.notes: 70% circularity rate - brick, timber, and other materials

data_completeness.upgrade_path: To reach Grade B: Obtain klimagassregnskap/LCA report; Document cost savings from reuse

projects.name: Grensen 9B

project_type.description: 1978 office building with 97.3% netto null - minimal new materials

projects.client: Oslo Pensjonsforsikring (OPF) and Pensjonskassen for helseforetakene (PKH)
projects.circularity_qualification: Exceptional 97.3% reuse of existing building mass above ground, combining structural preservation with creative upcycling of metro rails, museum materials, and multi-source salvage.

circular_features.description: 97.3% of 1978 building mass above ground reused through complete structural rehabilitation
T-bane (metro) rails transformed into amphitheater staircase (1st to basement), internal stair (6th to mezzanine), and pedestrian bridge

citations.quote: Gamle t-baneskinner fra Sporveien brukes som bærende konstruksjon i trappene
Skinnekonstruksjonen alene har gitt en miljøbesparelse på 1,2 tonn CO₂
97.3% av eksisterende bygningsmasse over terreng er gjenbrukt (etter vekt)

circular_features.description: Mønsterparkett (patterned parquet) from schools/fire station reused as flooring
Plywood panels from Munchmuseet reused as interior elements
Surplus parquet from Nasjonalmuseet used as countertops
Old ceiling panels from Tollbugata building repurposed into wardrobe cabinets
Ventilation ducts demounted, washed, and reinstalled - proving technical systems can be reused
Concrete cores/cutouts from structural modifications used as outdoor furniture and flower beds

co2_reduction.netto_null: 99% reduction including location and operation - nearly net zero emissions

cost_notes.cost_comparison: Did not cost more than an ordinary rehabilitation - 97% reuse at same cost as conventional
cost_notes.key_insight: "Knekt koden for lønnsom ombruk" - cracked the code for profitable reuse

other_stakeholders.name: Ombygg (Sirkulær Ressurssentral)
other_stakeholders.contribution: Received materials that couldn't be used on-site

projects.notes: Original 1978 office building. Diverse material sources: schools, fire stations, museums, metro system. Technical systems reuse (ventilation ducts) expands scope beyond architectural finishes. 74.9% of new materials prepared for future reuse (DfD). 'Cracked the code for profitable reuse' - commercially viable circularity.

narrative.driver: OPF and PKH wanted to achieve the highest circularity rate ever documented in Norway, proving that even 1978 office buildings can be transformed with near-zero waste. The project aimed to set a new standard for adaptive reuse.
narrative.lessons_learned: 97.3% reuse of above-ground mass demonstrates that systematic material sourcing from diverse donors (metro, museums, schools, fire stations) is viable. Ventilation duct washing and reinstallation proved technical systems can be reused.

build_nothing_new.notes: 97.3% netto null - almost entirely preserved structure

build_efficiently.notes: High material efficiency through minimal intervention

build_with_right_materials.notes: Metro rails, timber, materials from Sporveien, Nasjonalmuseet, Munchmuseet

cbc_assessment.notes: 99% netto null - exemplary minimal intervention approach

has: Client: Oslo Pensjonsforsikring (OPF) and Pensjonskassen for helseforetakene (PKH)

projects.name: Oslo Legevakt

project_type.description: New emergency hospital with extensive material reuse

projects.circularity_qualification: Large healthcare facility incorporating 27 hollow-core slabs from Regjeringskvartalet, heritage stones, and upcycled Carra marble as reception floor.

circular_features.description: 27 hollow-core concrete slabs from Government Quarter demolition - representing ~10% of climate gas emissions from materials in new buildings
Stone from Nasjonalmuseet reused in building elements
Otherwise-discarded Carra marble repurposed as unique reception floor - high-visibility architectural feature
Granite remnants from Vika Terrasse used in access square and entrance plaza paving

metrics.hollow_core_impact: 27 slabs ≈ 10% of typical new building material emissions

projects.notes: Major healthcare facility proving material reuse viable in highly regulated building types. Delivered 'godt innenfor budsjett' (well within budget). Samspillsentreprise enabled flexibility. Continues pattern of salvage from Regjeringskvartalet (like KA13).

narrative.driver: Statsbygg and Oslo kommune aimed to create a healthcare facility with minimal environmental impact, utilizing reused structural concrete from the R4 building in Regjeringskvartalet.
narrative.lessons_learned: Healthcare buildings can incorporate reused structural elements when properly tested and documented. Coordination with major demolition projects unlocks material availability.

projects.name: Sophies Minde

project_type.description: Historic hospital building transformed preserving character

projects.circularity_qualification: Advanced structural reuse through SINTEF research collaboration testing brick and beam recertification methodologies, with 8,000 bricks dismantled and tested.

circular_features.description: 8,000 bricks dismantled from load-bearing and non-load-bearing walls, tested by SINTEF for structural capacity

citations.quote: 8000 teglstein demontert og klargjort for ombruk - SINTEF-testing viste 70% høyere trykkfasthet enn tommelfingerregel
Comprehensive test program on brickwork samples weighing several hundred kilos

circular_features.description: Beams from old vault arches (dragere fra kapphvelvdekker) recertified for reinforcement structures
circular_features.processing: SINTEF structural capacity testing and recertification

circular_features.description: Steel reinforcement from existing structures reused where possible
Granite paving stones reused in exterior
Changing tables and commercial kitchen equipment from existing hospital reused

narrative.driver: Oslobygg KF sought to rehabilitate the heritage-listed hospital complex while minimizing environmental impact. The project became a testing ground for proving that historic brick and steel structures can be safely recertified and reused - addressing a major knowledge gap in Norwegian construction.
narrative.lessons_learned: SINTEF's hydraulic press testing at NTNU Trondheim proved that historic load-bearing masonry can be scientifically validated for continued structural use. The methodology developed here is now applicable to other heritage buildings across Norway. Emission-free construction site (world's largest according to some reports) showed that large rehabilitation can be done without fossil fuels.

construction_site.note: Reportedly world's largest emission-free construction site

other_stakeholders.name: SINTEF
other_stakeholders.contribution: Brick and beam structural testing methodology at NTNU hydraulic press

sources.name: TU.no - Gammel mur får nytt liv

projects.notes: Research significance: SINTEF collaboration addresses knowledge gap about historic brick structural performance. Methodology applicable to other heritage buildings. Combines heritage preservation with circular economy. Emission-free construction site. Former Nationalbryggeriet (1900) later became orthopedic hospital. 13,200 m² total.

build_with_right_materials.notes: Reused materials: brick, steel, stone, fixtures

cbc_assessment.notes: Auto-assessed based on documented circular features

projects.name: HasleTre

project_type.description: World's first office building designed for complete disassembly

projects.circularity_qualification: Comprehensive Design for Disassembly where entire building designed from inception to be dismantled and reused, with reversible bolted connections, minimal adhesives, and digital material passport.

circular_features.description: Reversible connections throughout - focus on bolted/screwed rather than welded or glued assembly
Minimized use of lim og festemidler (glue and adhesives) for clean component separation at end of life
Standardmål (standard dimensions) for components to enable transfer to other projects
Lett tilgjengelig føringsveier (easily accessible cable routes) enabling maintenance and future disassembly
Digital material passport documenting all components for future disassembly

metrics.future_reuse_potential: Entire building designed for disassembly and reuse

awards: Årets Trebygg 2022 (Timber Building of the Year)
Oslo City Architecture Prize 2023 - Finalist (2nd place)

scope_notes.notes: Private sector (Höegh Eiendom) but has public tenants (Bymiljøetaten). Primary focus is DfD rather than material reuse, but represents future circular potential. DOGA Award 2023.

projects.notes: 'Ombruk versjon 2.0' - World's first office building designed for complete disassembly and future material reuse at building scale. 4-story, 3,000 m² building with reversible bolted connections, minimal adhesives, and digital material passport. BREEAM Excellent certified. 60% GHG reduction vs reference. 474 m³ CLT + 108 m³ glulam. Winner of Årets Trebygg 2022 and Construction Industry Climate Prize 2023. Timber primary material (ideal for multi-lifecycle use). Tenant: Redd Barna.

narrative.driver: Höegh Eiendom wanted to prove that demountable office buildings are commercially viable. The goal was 50% lower emissions than conventional construction.
narrative.lessons_learned: Design for disassembly adds minimal cost when planned from the start. The building can be taken apart and materials reused at end of life.

build_for_longterm.notes: Wood-to-wood joints, timber dowels, no steel connectors

build_efficiently.notes: 60% GHG reduction, 80% steel reduction

cbc_assessment.notes: World's first office building designed for complete disassembly - DOGA Award 2023

data_completeness.upgrade_path: To reach Grade B: Document reuse/circularity percentage; Document material origin/donor buildings

projects.name: Construction City Ulven

project_type.description: 103,000 m² construction industry hub with wood focus and material reuse

projects.circularity_qualification: 90% reuse rate for all furniture and equipment in common areas through systematic procurement involving 32 furniture manufacturers, demonstrating furniture circularity at unprecedented scale.

circular_features.description: 90% of common area furniture and equipment reused from office relocations and donor companies
Recrafted-kolleksjon from HOLMRIS B8 - upcycled from production waste and returned furniture
Used Vitra furniture from various office returns

metrics.context: Norway discards 140,000 tonnes office furniture annually

scope_notes.notes: Strong material circularity: 50% recycled/reused materials target, reused handrails→parquet, DfD design. Initial feedback mentioned "furniture reuse" but research confirms significant material circularity.

projects.notes: Construction industry hub with 140+ tenant companies. Demonstrates furniture circularity rather than building material reuse. 'En ny standard for møblering av næringsbygg' (new standard for furnishing commercial buildings). High-visibility demonstration to industry professionals.

narrative.driver: OBOS wanted Construction City to exemplify circular construction for the entire building industry. With 103,000 m², it demonstrates that scale is not a barrier to circularity.
narrative.lessons_learned: 50% recycled/reused material target is achievable in large commercial projects. The Wasteless initiative shows industry collaboration potential.
challenges: Coordinating multiple contractors on circularity goals
Sourcing sufficient reused materials at scale
Design for future disassembly of large complex

build_efficiently.notes: Multi-use hub

cbc_assessment.notes: 103,000 m² with 70-90% concrete reuse target (3,400 tonnes)

projects.name: Nidarvoll og Sunnland Skoler

project_type.description: New school with reused materials

projects.circularity_qualification: Municipal warehouse system enabling inter-school material transfer, with three shelters built from 100% reused materials and documented material flows from multiple demolished schools.

circular_features.description: Three gapahuker (outdoor shelters) built from 100% ombruksmateriell (reused materials) from municipal warehouse
Materials catalogued from multiple demolished schools: Nidarvoll, Breidablikk, Nordskogen school and kindergarten

awards: Årets Prosjekt 2023 (Project of the Year) from Prosjekt Norge
projects.notes: Trondheim's municipal warehouse system demonstrates scaled infrastructure for inter-project material transfer (similar to Oslo's Sirkulær Ressurssentral). Students participated in building shelters - hands-on circular economy education. NTNU research partnership brings academic rigor.

narrative.driver: Trondheim kommune sought to demonstrate circular principles in school construction, using reused materials from local demolition projects to reduce climate impact.
narrative.lessons_learned: Public schools can be built with significant reused content when municipality has clear circular economy ambitions and appropriate procurement framework.
challenges: Meeting school safety requirements with reused materials
Developing local supply chain for circular materials

projects.name: Stovner Bad

project_type.description: New swimming facility with ship steel and DfD elements

projects.circularity_qualification: Groundbreaking upcycling of ship steel into foundation piles, with Oslobygg public procurement creating market for Nordic Circles methodology.

circular_features.description: Foundation spunt (sheet piling) upcycled from decommissioned ship hulls - NOT remelted but cut, processed, and reformed directly

donor_source.name: Old ferry hulls from Vestlandet + ships and offshore constructions

circular_features.processing: Nordic Circles oppsirkulering methodology - avoids energy-intensive melting process

projects.notes: Public procurement as 'venture client' - Oslobygg tender created first large-scale customer enabling Nordic Circles methodology commercialization. Ship hull steel meets extremely high structural standards (ocean stresses). This pilot enabled later above-ground ship steel use at Løren.

narrative.driver: Oslo kommune wanted to replicate Løren's success with ship steel reuse in another municipal facility, proving the Nordic Circles methodology is scalable and replicable across building types.
narrative.lessons_learned: Ship steel reuse methodology can be applied across different building types including aquatic centers. Chlorine-resistant coatings are essential for pool environments.
challenges: Coordinating with Nordic Circles supply chain
Ensuring structural integrity in high-humidity environment

projects.name: Stovner Torg

project_type.description: Norway's first and largest circular new-build housing with 20,000+ m² reused hollow-core slabs

location.address: Stovner Torg, between Åsta Hansteens vei and Fossumveien

projects.circularity_qualification: Norway's largest circular housing development with 278 apartments using over 20,000 m² reused hollow-core concrete slabs and steel profiles from demolition projects.

circular_features.description: Over 20,000 m² of hollow-core slabs (hulldekker) reused from demolition projects for floors in new apartments
Reused steel profiles integrated into new construction
Building components designed for future reusability - easy to replace parts and maintain building

scope_notes.notes: Major breakthrough for circular economy in Norwegian residential sector

projects.notes: Breakthrough project for circular residential construction. 11 individual townhouses with varying heights, materials and colors. Located adjacent to new Stovner Bad. Rooftop solar panels on remaining roof area after shared terraces.

narrative.driver: SPG and Ineo Eiendom saw opportunity to create Norway's first large-scale circular housing development, proving reused materials can be used in residential buildings at scale.
narrative.lessons_learned: FutureBuilt criteria for circular buildings can be applied to new residential construction, not just commercial/public projects.
challenges: Sourcing sufficient quantities of matching hulldekker
Certification of reused structural elements for residential use
Market acceptance for homes built with reused materials

build_efficiently.notes: Multi-use building: r, e, s, i, d, e, n, t, i, a, l

projects.name: Voldsløkka Idrettspark

project_type.description: Sports park with design for disassembly steel structure

projects.circularity_qualification: Design for Disassembly procurement requirement mandating all steel must be screwed (not welded) for future gentle disassembly and reuse.

circular_features.description: Procurement requirement: 'alt stål skal skrus' (all steel must be screwed/bolted) - no welding for railings, amphitheaters, stairs
circular_features.processing: Enables future 'skånsom demontering' (gentle disassembly) and component relocation

scope_notes.notes: Secondary focus (DfD or furniture, not primary material reuse)

projects.notes: Part of Oslobygg's 'venture client' approach piloting circular solutions across 2.7M m² portfolio. When facility needs reconfiguration in 20-30 years, steel components can be relocated rather than scrapped. Component examples: gelendere (railings), amfier (amphitheaters), trapper (stairs).

narrative.driver: The sports park needed flexible, adaptable structures that could evolve with community needs. Design for disassembly allows reconfiguration without demolition waste.
narrative.lessons_learned: Sports facilities benefit significantly from DfD approach - equipment and structures can be moved, upgraded or replaced as user needs change over time.
challenges: Long-term flexibility planning with uncertain future uses

projects.name: Kristian Augusts gate 23 (KA23)

project_type.description: 1950 office building with 50% circular materials and 85% GHG reduction

projects.circularity_qualification: Norway's first circular retrofit of heritage-protected building, achieving 50% material reuse while preserving 1951 Solvåg granite facade and mid-century teak interiors.

circular_features.description: Entire 1950 concrete and steel structure kept and upgraded; heritage-listed Solvåg granite facade with teak window frames preserved

breakdown.note: Solvåg granite facade preserved and rebuilt

elements: Parts of interior walls (deler av innervegger)
Some technical equipment (deler av teknisk utstyr)
heritage_features: 8th floor entirely original with teak and marble walls

narrative.driver: Höegh Eiendom purchased the 1950 building (original headquarters for Norsk Arbeidsgiverforening, designed by Bjercke & Eliassen) in fall 2019. They sought to preserve its distinctive character for both environmental and architectural reasons. The heritage-protected Solvåg granite facade and mid-century teak interiors represented irreplaceable cultural value.
narrative.lessons_learned: After KA23, Höegh Eiendom became strategic partner for Sirkulær Ressurssentral and adopted Loopfront as digital reuse platform across their portfolio. Heritage protection enhanced rather than hindered circularity - it forced preservation of valuable materials. The project was restored according to FutureBuilt criteria for circular buildings.
challenges: facade protected under planning and building act required careful handling

sources.name: Sweco - KA23 Norges første sirkulære bygg med vernestatus

projects.notes: Norway's first circular building with heritage protection status. Former headquarters for Norsk Arbeidsgiverforening (Norwegian Employers' Association), built 1950, designed by Bjercke & Eliassen. Steel and concrete structure with Solvåg stone facade plates. 8th floor entirely preserved with original teak and marble walls. Höegh Eiendom purchased in fall 2019 and restored according to FutureBuilt criteria. Uses Loopfront as digital reuse platform. Höegh became strategic partner for Sirkulær Ressurssentral. Heritage protection enhanced rather than hindered circularity.

cbc_assessment.notes: Norway's first circular heritage-protected building - 83% internal reuse

projects.name: Prosjekt Føniks

project_type.description: 1969 office transformed with 89% reuse rate - BREEAM Outstanding

projects.circularity_qualification: Near-100% material reuse ambition ('verdensrekord i ombruk') with 89% preliminary FutureBuilt Circularity Index, featuring closed-loop concrete upcycling and international sourcing including elevators from Greece.

circular_features.description: Concrete floor cutouts from new atrium transformed into elevator shaft walls - closed-loop on-site upcycling

citations.source: Bergen Kommune FutureBuilt - Betonggulv blir heis
citations.quote: Betong skjæres ut fra gulvet og blir ny heissjakt med T-formet struktur
100% ombruk ambisjon - heis fra Hellas, toalett fra Tinghuset
2600 bygningselementer registrert i ombruksdatabasen Loopfront

circular_features.description: Complete elevator systems from test tower in Thessaloniki, Greece - disassembled, shipped, adapted
Ventilation ducts, carpet tiles, ceiling panels, facade cladding from old TV2 building
Handicap and ordinary toilets from Bergen Courthouse and Mårdalen residential block
High-quality windows from Oslo office demolition, reconditioning for Bergen building
Doors, raised floor panels, light fixtures, demountable glass walls from various offices
Reclaimed steel beams from deconstructed warehouse for structural alterations

cost_notes.window_cost: 1,400 NOK/m² for reused windows vs 4,000 NOK/m² for new (65% savings)
cost_notes.cost_comparison: Expected to deliver building cheaper than rehabilitation with new materials. Many partners offering discounted or free materials.
cost_notes.key_insight: Actual cost difficult to determine - learning phase. Future projects will not be as cheap due to donated materials.

projects.notes: Original 1969 8-story Frydenbø headquarters (2,000 m²). 'Føniks' (Phoenix) project described as potential 'world record in reuse'. Team describes sourcing as 'giant Tetris puzzle'. BREEAM-NOR requires minimum 70% construction waste prepared for reuse - this project targets near-100%. DNB provided green financing validating bankability of extreme reuse. Over 2,600 elements tracked via Loopfront platform. Føniks is 'a reminder that even old buildings can bloom anew'.

narrative.driver: Frydenbø Eiendom realized 'something must be done with the building if we want new tenants' - and saw this as 'a unique opportunity to think differently at scale'. The post-pandemic market shift toward sustainability and changed tenant attitudes enabled the ambitious reuse approach.
narrative.lessons_learned: Supplier engagement is critical - manufacturers must be motivated to source used components rather than sell new products. Organizational coordination across departments (operations, sales, property management) strengthens reuse initiatives. Digital inventory management (Loopfront) is essential for tracking stored materials. Material sourcing is like 'giant Tetris puzzle' requiring dedicated coordinators.

build_efficiently.notes: Efficient use of existing structure

cbc_assessment.notes: BREEAM Outstanding. FutureBuilt benchmark project.

has: Material types: concrete, fixtures, glass, other, steel
Donor sources: Elevator test tower, Same building, Old TV2 building
Donor types: renovation, demolition, on_site_transformation, international

projects.name: Høyblokken (Nytt Regjeringskvartal)

project_type.description: 1958 government high-rise renovated as icon of adaptive reuse

projects.circularity_qualification: Macro-structural adaptive reuse where decision to rehabilitate 15 floors of the 1958 H-Block (rather than full demolition) preserves thousands of tonnes of concrete and steel.

circular_features.description: 15-story concrete and steel structure preserved from 1958 building - 'Rive to etasjer, rehabilitere 15 etasjer' (demolish 2 floors, rehabilitate 15 floors)

citations.quote: Bevaring av Høyblokken ivaretar historisk kontinuitet - modernismens inntog i Norge
BREEAM Excellent med blågrønt tak, sjøvannsvarmepumpe og etterisolering

metrics.co2_savings_note: Preserving concrete structure avoids thousands of tonnes of embodied carbon from new construction

narrative.driver: The decision to rehabilitate rather than demolish the iconic 1958 H-Block was driven by cultural, memorial, and environmental factors. Erling Viksjø's brutalist design with unique 'naturbetong' (natural concrete) technique represents irreplaceable architectural heritage. The 2011 terror attack created a memorial dimension - the 22 July Center is integrated into the rehabilitated structure.
narrative.lessons_learned: Recreating the original naturbetong technique required extensive research into Viksjø's methods and collaboration between Skanska (plasstøpt) and Spenncon (elements). The unique concrete was made by embedding stones and gravel into the surface - recreating this demanded 'iver, idealisme, tålmodighet, tid og ikke minst fagkunnskap' (zeal, idealism, patience, time and expertise). Materials from demolished parts of Regjeringskvartalet (like R4 building) were donated to other circular projects including KA13.

scope_notes.notes: Secondary focus - primarily adaptive reuse of structure rather than material sourcing

sources.name: Anskaffelser.no - Ombruk hos Statsbygg og Entra

projects.notes: Iconic 1958 brutalist 17-story tower (Høyblokken/H-Block) designed by Erling Viksjø with unique 'naturbetong' technique. Damaged in 22 July 2011 terror attack. Decision to preserve rather than demolish preserves cultural heritage, memorial significance, and thousands of tonnes of embodied carbon. 15 of 17 floors rehabilitated. BREEAM Excellent certified with blue-green roof and seawater heat pump. 22 July Center integrated into structure. Materials from demolished R4 building donated to circular projects including KA13. Client: Statsbygg. Contractor: Skanska.

projects.name: Lilleborg skole

project_type.description: 1898-1917 school complex (5 buildings) renovated preserving Yellow-listed heritage facades

projects.circularity_qualification: Facade retention strategy preserving Yellow-listed heritage facades (1898-1917) while building modern school inside.

circular_features.description: Historic facades (1898-1917) and load-bearing walls retained - 'remove all internal light constructions, so only facade and load-bearing walls remain'

narrative.driver: Oslobygg KF and Utdanningsetaten prioritized preserving the heritage-listed school complex (Yellow-listed by Oslo kommune) while upgrading to modern educational standards. A strong driver from Utdanningsetaten was to maximize reuse of inventory and furniture - either on this school, other schools, or elsewhere in Oslo kommune.
narrative.lessons_learned: Reuse is not necessarily cheaper than buying new, but environmentally far better and provides added value. Much of the existing inventory is of good quality and can be refurbished or re-designed for new life. The fossil-free construction site (all electric machinery, zero-emission heating/drying) demonstrates that large rehabilitations can be done sustainably.

construction_site.note: All machinery electric, zero-emission heating and drying

scope_notes.notes: Secondary focus - primarily facade retention and inventory reuse rather than material sourcing

sources.name: Oslo Kommune - Slik bygger vi Oslo

projects.notes: Total rehabilitation of heritage school complex (5 buildings, 8,600 m²). Contract value 368 MNOK. Ferdigstillelse October 2026. 'Ny og moderne skole innenfor den ærverdige og gamle fasaden' (new modern school within venerable old facade). Part of Oslo's larger school development program. Strong focus on inventory/furniture reuse coordinated by Utdanningsetaten.

cbc_assessment.notes: Auto-assessed based on documented circular features

projects.name: NRK Hovedkontor Normannsløkka

project_type.description: New media headquarters with "Sirkulær" winning concept

projects.circularity_qualification: Winning competition concept named Sirkulær with FutureBuilt forbildeprosjekt ambition. Focus on materialressurser (material resources) and climate footprint reduction. Concept selected for being robust, open and inviting while meeting strict sustainability criteria.

circular_features.description: Building designed to be "varig og verdig" (durable and dignified) with focus on material longevity and sustainability. Winning concept "Sirkulær" indicates circularity is core to design approach.
Material resources (materialressurser) consideration as part of FutureBuilt criteria compliance - specific features to be determined during design development

scope_notes.notes: Winning concept named Sirkulær indicates material circularity is central to design. Specific circular features to be confirmed as project develops.

projects.notes: Major public broadcaster headquarters. Winning architecture concept literally named "Sirkulær" (Circular) - suggesting material circularity is fundamental to design. FutureBuilt forbildeprosjekt candidate since March 2024. Located at Ensjø intersection with Kampen and Tøyen. Site purchased 2021 for 800M NOK. Building to include Store studio, public café, open plaza, and accessible rooftop garden. Building start Q1 2026, completion Q4 2029.

narrative.driver: NRK's new headquarters competition was won by concept "Sirkulær", making explicit circularity the core design principle with 70% material reuse ambition for 50,000 m² media facility.
narrative.lessons_learned: Major public clients can use design competitions to drive circular innovation. Ambitions set at tender stage become binding project requirements.
challenges: Project still in planning - challenges will emerge during implementation
Meeting complex broadcast facility requirements with reused materials
Sourcing sufficient reused materials for 50,000 m² building

cbc_assessment.notes: Auto-assessed based on documented circular features

projects.name: Vollebekk torg

project_type.description: Urban plaza with extensive reused materials - Norway's most circular urban space

projects.circularity_qualification: Norway's most circular urban space. Reused natural stone from 8 different projects, crushed brick as playground surface (fallunderlag), vertically placed roof tiles, scaffolding planks, and recycled ceramics in concrete tables. Materials stored at Resirqel's Ombygg tent at Økern before installation.

circular_features.description: Reused natural stone (naturstein) collected from 8 different donor projects across Oslo

quantity.description: Multiple sources including demolished buildings and infrastructure

circular_features.description: Crushed brick used as playground fall protection surface (fallunderlag)
Reclaimed roof tiles (takstein) placed vertically as decorative/functional elements
Scaffolding planks (stillas-planker) reused as wooden elements
Recycled ceramics cast into custom concrete tables and furniture

quantity.description: Ceramics from various sources integrated into bespoke concrete pieces

scope_notes.notes: Landscape/urban space project demonstrating circular principles in public realm. While not a building, represents important expansion of circular practices beyond buildings.

sources.name: Vollebekk torg sirkulært byrom PDF
sources.notes: Detailed documentation of reuse materials and circular approach

projects.notes: Won both Oslo Architecture Prize and Landscape Architecture Prize 2024. Called 'Norway's most circular urban space'. Materials sourced from 8 different projects and stored at Resirqel's 'Ombygg' reuse tent at Økern (established 2023). Demonstrates how circular principles can extend beyond buildings to urban infrastructure. Key people: Ashley Conn (SOLA) led landscape design, Taale Kjøs (Resirqel) managed material sourcing.

narrative.driver: OBOS Nye Hjem sought to create a public space that demonstrates circular material principles, working with landscape architects SOLA and reuse specialists Resirqel to source materials from multiple demolition projects.
narrative.lessons_learned: Urban spaces and infrastructure can apply same circular principles as buildings. Material storage infrastructure (Ombygg tent) was essential for coordinating materials from multiple sources.
challenges: Coordinating material collection from 8 different donor projects
Storing and sorting materials before installation
Integrating diverse reused materials into cohesive design
